description.narrative: Strengthening capacities for sustainable development finance in the Commonwealth of Independent States (CIS) region

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
Activity1. 1.1 Number of workshops and trainings for potential borrowers of the Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund preferably with no less than 30% of women-borrowers 1.2 Number of gender-sensitive pre-feasibility studies, business plans, assessments developed under the technical assistance to potential borrowers of the Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund 1.3 Number of projects that received Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund loan out of the all projects supported under Activity 1
Activity 2. 2.1 Number of gender-sensitive pre-feasibility and feasibility studies, business plans, assessments, etc. developed under the technical assistance to potential borrowers of the Eurasian Development Bank 2.2 Number of lending products and credit lines supported by the project

comment.narrative:
Activity 1. - Even though RKDF (Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund) resources are highly concessional for the Kyrgyz businesses, there is a limited number of projects in its pipeline due to the low capacity of local businesses in project preparation. Low capacity of applicants can inhibit the use of concessional development finance when it is mostly needed and widely available. - Lack of a steady flow of well prepared projects for the Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund support is holding back development investment in the CIS countries and Kyrgyzstan in particular - Out of 184 applications for direct financing by the Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund only seven have been funded and five included in the pipeline for further consideration.
Activity 2 - One of the barriers in CIS countries is to mobilizing resources from IFIs is the lack of understanding and poor skills of potential project applicants and implementing agencies in adhering to IFIs standard procedures. - IFIs have limited information on and understanding of the specifics of economic activities in the local context. Scope for public support for their projects is narrow. Targeted efforts are needed to engage stakeholders in inclusive participation in IFIs’ projects and to ensure the projects effectiveness and sustainability through the participatory approach.

1.1. Seven 4-days trainings for entrepreneurs to strengthen their capacities to prepare the qualitative start-up business projects under the Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund start-up programme has started in November 2020 and will continue until February 2021. Up to 160 enterpeneurs are trained within this trainings;
1.2. The feasibility studies for 2 projects (total requested loan amount of both projects is 4,380,000 USD) were completed and the projects were submitted to the RKDF for consideration of project financing: the concept of one project was approved by the RKDF, and the second project is in the process of review by the RKDF. 5 additional business projects with developed feasability studies have been submitted to RKDF in December 2020.
1.3. One of the sectors that have been heavily impacted by the COVID 19 was tourism. The business project, the concept of which has been approved by the RKDF was in tourism sector. Due to the economic situation, the business owner decided to temporarily halt the implementation of the project until 2021. Thus, he withdrew his application for financing. The epidemiological situation connected with COVID-19, as well as the increase and fluctuation of USD, had and continues to have the negative impact on the private sector. The deterioration of the financial situation of the businesses and the further uncertainty of the development of events affect the decisions of entrepreneurs about the need and possibilities to attract financial resources for their business at the current moment and in the near perspective. In the process of identifying potential business projects, many entrepreneurs expressed their unwillingness to take loans under the current economic situation, which influenced and affects the number of attracted business projects.
2.1. No feasabiilty study under component 2 have been developed yet. The identification of the business project is still in process.
2.2. During the first quarter of 2020, the consultant responsible for the development of new loan products in the priority thematic areas for the EDB and the second-tier banks conducted the study of the international business models and credit lines of international development banks and commercial banks, primarily focused on improving energy efficiency and sustainable agricultural production and other areas, including microcredit financing, small and medium business support, trade finance, and others. Within the framework of the assignment, the consultant also visited 12 partner banks located in Belarus, Armenia and Kyrgyzstan. The interviews with the managers and specialists of partner banks allowed to get feedback on their practice of working with the EDB and other international development institutions and funds for attracting credit lines. Based on the results of the conducted study and interviews, the consultant proposed 17 options of credit lines to the EDB, with adjustments to the terms of existing products, and new products - credit lines customized according to the requests of the partner banks and the specifics of market development in specific countries (7 credit lines for Belarus, 5 credit lines for Armenia and 5 credit lines for Kyrgyzstan).

- at least 1 of workshops and trainings for potential borrowers of the Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund preferably with no less than 30% of women-borrowers - development of at least 2 pre-feasibility studies, business plans, assessments developed under the technical assistance to potential borrowers of the Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund - at least 40% of projects that received Russian-Kyrgyz Development Fund loan out of the all projects supported under Activity 1 - development of at least 1 pre-feasibility studies, business plans, assessments developed under the technical assistance to potential borrowers of the Eurasian Development Bank; - at least 1 of lending products and credit lines supported by the project

a) 4 trainings and workshops have been conducted, including: 1. In August 2019, the EMPRETEC training workshop took place with participation of 28 participants, most of which were entrepreneurs. The participants included the RKDF clients as well 2. In September 2019, 3 trainings on RKDF Start-up financing program have been conducted for entrepreneurs in Naryn, Batken and Talas oblasts. b) 6 business projects were approved by the Council in 2019 and were submitted to the the consulting company for the development of feasibility studies in October 2019. As of the end of January 2020, these business projects have the following status: the agreements of co-financing the development of feasibility studies have been signed with owners of 4 business projects: the fully developed feasibility studies of 2 business projects have been submitted to the RKDF and are in the process of review by the RKDF, the 3rd business project is to be submitted to the RKDF in February 2020 and the 4th project is at the stage of development; 1 business project is on hold status: the company has applied parallelly for financing in the frame of the state program on financing the development of regions and awaiting for their decision; 1 business project withdrew its application. c) Due to the requirement of the Eurasian Development Bank that the implementation of measures to identify projects for financing and the development of feasibility studies, as part of the Activity related to cooperation with the EDB, should come as the next step to the development of a co-financing mechanism, the implementation of this measure has been postponed until 2020. d) The consultant was recruited and started the assignment in January 2020. the report is due in March 2020
